author: Joe Morgenstern
title: ‘The Assassin’ Review: To Kill or Not to Kill
text: 0 COMMENTS More Reviews ‘Room’ ‘Bridge of Spies’ ‘Beasts of No Nation’ All I know about ninth-century Chinese history is that it took place after the eighth century and before the 10th century. Armed with this insight, I did my best to follow the intricacies of “The Assassin,” a film, by Hou Hsiao-Hsien, that Taiwan has designated as its entry in this year’s Oscars. Now I know that the heroine, a lissome killer named Nie Yinniang ( Shu Qi), is going through a crisis of conscience, having been ordered to kill the man she loves. But I also know “The Assassin” to be so ravishingly lovely that tracking the plot is far less important than luxuriating in the images. Long shots draw you in, then make you work to see what’s happening. Lords and ladies in regal rooms are seen from afar through gauzy curtains and coils of smoke. The long-haired assassin stands at a distance, clad in black boots and a long black coat The cinematographer was Mark Lee Ping Bing. His long suit is beauty.
